posts.cooked:
Hey everyone,

I’ve been wanting to learn application development (with Flutter, namely) and I want to make something FRC -related, maybe even something useful for FRC code development.

The idea is this: A project in which you can create WPILib projects with templates and examples, manage vendor dependencies and automatically check for updates, one-click installations for other addons like YAGSL and AdvantageKit, configuration panels for addons, stuff like that. Leaving the only thing left to do being the actual programming for the robot. Effectively everything you can already do in VS Code, just simplified in a great-looking UI.

Of course, just like every program meant to make a more complex job easier, this would help making projects quick and easy as well as making changing YAGSL configuration and stuff just a little bit easier and faster, but then again it reduces customizability. Then again, one could go back and customize to their heart’s content after project creation… I don’t have a concrete idea in my head yet.

My question for the time being is: Would your team benefit from an application like this? Do you think other teams would as well? The primary purpose of this would be to teach myself application development, but if I can end up making something useful, double win.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

Effectively everything you can already do in VS Code, just simplified in a great-looking UI.

I think you already highlighted my main reaction to this, doesn’t the WPILib VS Code plugin already provide most of this functionality in a GUI already?

I’m not as familiar with YAGSL and if there’s already a GUI configurator like there is inside Tuner X for the Phoenix 6 swerve template, but that might be a better scope to start out with. Doing this as a contribution to an existing open-source project like YAGSL also means you get the benefit of having that whole support structure to help you as well as making it more likely that it continues to be maintained past when you’re done working on it.

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
Knufire:

YAGSL and if there’s already a GUI configurator

YAGSL has a gui configurator, but last I used it, it wasn’t that useful or obvious what thing meant, it just took your inputs and made the actual json files

Knufire:

Doing this as a contribution to an existing open-source project like YAGSL also means you get the benefit of having that whole support structure to help you as well as making it more likely that it continues to be maintained past when you’re done working on it.

That is an excellent point, and it’s a good way to break this objective into sections for my own learning. The only reason that I don’t like the idea of an app dedicated to simply configuring existing YAGSL files is that it’s not exactly worth downloading an app only for that purpose when you can just go edit the JSON files without much difficulty. If it were a larger scoped application, it might actually be worth downloading. As I said though, I do agree that it’s a good starting point.

Ankur-Raghavan:

YAGSL has a gui configurator, but last I used it, it wasn’t that useful or obvious what thing meant, it just took your inputs and made the actual json files

That is something I did not mention but I want it to be a key feature in this application: Providing detailed and helpful summaries of each field and how it affects the robot, as well as perhaps adding preset values for certain fields like the grip coefficient, for example, could have presets for TPU on smooth concrete, TPU on field carpet, etc. I know this information is available with a pretty quick internet search, but to have it all there would be nice. Another slight disadvantage is that the existing YAGSL config page, if I am thinking of the same one, is web-based and may not be available in a FRC event.

We’ve been looking into making an app for swerve drive configuration but haven’t made any progress on it yet. (We’re focused on the C++ port and then a few quality of life fixes). If you want to make an app we will try to support and maintain it afterwards. Ideally we would have something like the tuner x swerve generator. I have even discussed the exact steps necessary and what the application flow for this is in the YAGSL discord server , if you do decide you want to make this you won’t be starting from step 0.

Good luck! Let me know if you do want to pursue this!!

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

manage vendor dependencies and automatically check for updates

You can see that this is one of our priorities that I have been working on.  I want it to be an extension in VSCode that teams can use easily without needing a separate program.  No promises on anything and this is still very early on but this is something like what it might look like functionally (the UI appearance can/will be cleaned up considerably): image_720 311×720 70.3 KB

image_720 311×720 70.3 KB

image_720 311×720 70.3 KB

link_counts.title: WPILib Championship Wrap-Up and Our Roadmap

posts.cooked:
nstrike:

We’ve been looking into making an app for swerve drive configuration but haven’t made any progress on it yet.

That would be pretty cool. I still need to learn all of the UI stuff for Flutter before I can get into NetworkTables and controlling the robot. (Is there place I can learn about the NetworkTables protocol and how to use it in my own apps?)

jdaming:

You can see that this is one of our priorities that I have been working on. I want it to be an extension in VSCode that teams can use easily without needing a separate program.

If this was directly implemented in VS Code, that would be way better than an external app. Just makes managing and installing vendor deps that much faster without having to grab the URLs for each.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

Is there place I can learn about the NetworkTables protocol and how to use it in my own apps?

Have you read all of the documentation in FRC Docs ?

link_counts.title: What is NetworkTables — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
@AmoryG Had written about this somewhere, but here is their TS impl.

Web components to build custom dashboards for the FIRST Robotics Competition - frc-web-components/frc-web-components

There’s also this package

Client for FRC Network Tables. Latest version: 1.7.2, last published: 4 years ago. Start using wpilib-nt-client in your project by running `npm i wpilib-nt-client`. There are 3 other projects in the npm registry using wpilib-nt-client.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
A dart implementation of network tables is here:

Dart package for the WPILib NT4 protocol. Contribute to mjansen4857/nt4 development by creating an account on GitHub.

link_counts.title: GitHub - mjansen4857/nt4: Dart package for the WPILib NT4 protocol

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: @Gold87 can probably talk about he used NetworkTables with Flutter for his shuffleboard alternative.
Thank you! This is what I was looking for.
